author: Samantha Gee
title: Abel Tasman National Park generates $1m revenue after record-breaking season
text:
Abel Tasman National Park generates $1m revenue after record-breaking season SAMANTHA GEE Last updated 10:11, September 10 2015 MARION VAN DIJK/Stuff.co.nz 
A record number of visitors made their way to the Abel Tasman National Park last summer, bringing in an extra $1 million in revenue for the Department of Conservation. 
A record number of visitors to the Abel Tasman National Park has generated more than $1 million revenue for the Department of Conservation for the first time. 
An estimated 228,000 people visited the park between July 2014 and June 2015, paying more than $1m in campground and hut fees. 
Department of Conservation operations manager Mark Townsend said the department had collated comprehensive visitor statistics for the first time in the 2014/2015 year. In the past, it had estimated there were around 160,000 visitors to the park annually. Marion van Dijk 
Trampers walk along Anapai Beach in the Abel Tasman National Park. 
"The real challenge for us is to measure the day visitors that enter the park," said Townsend. "To try and estimate those numbers we draw on our concession operators, that's a big chunk of our visitors coming in by water taxi. They hop on at Marahau or Kaiteriteri and travel around by foot or kayak." 
The department estimates around 75 per cent of those visiting the Abel Tasman are day visitors. 
"It is the first year we have broken that million dollar milestone," Townsend said. "It has been steadily increasing and because of the good summer we had it has jumped up." Last year, there were over 75,000 individual bednights at Abel Tasman huts and campsites, excluding the Totaranui campsite. A new 34-bed hut was built at Anchorage 18 months ago and was fully booked for the month of January and at full capacity for more than a third of the year. Despite the perception that the Abel Tasman is targeted mainly at overseas visitors, 40 per cent of those who stay overnight in the park are Kiwis. After New Zealanders, Germans were the next most frequent overnight visitors, followed by American then French visitors. 
A breakdown of visitors to the Abel Tasman National Park between July 2014 and June 2015. 
Wilsons Abel Tasman chief executive Darryl Wilson said having access to visitor statistics was a positive step in the transparency between DOC and tourism operators in the park. 
"I have been lobbying for this to be available in a useable format for operators to understand what is happening," said Wilson. "It is really important as a tourism industry we understand the figures and know where people are coming from." 
He said DOC had developed a stronger commercial focus and they had been more actively promoting the Great Walks, targeting overseas visitors in particular. "Looking at the standard of accommodation that is starting to appear, it is a very cost effective holiday in some of New Zealand's best environments," said Wilson. As a result it was no surprise the park was becoming increasingly popular and he questioned whether taxpayers were subsidising accommodation for international visitors. He said the recent statistics raised an opportunity to discuss other payment options for international visitors, such as concession fees. Most places in the world charged a premium for access to national parks and visitors to New Zealand often expected the same would apply here, said Wilson. Marahau Sea Kayaks and Abel Tasman Aqua Taxi commercial director Brendan Alborn said he had noticed growth in visitors over the last two years and said it was a result of good weather and increased international arrivals. Marion van Dijk 
Alison Maccoll of Christchurch near Marahau after visiting Abel Tasman National Park for a day walk. 
"I find it really difficult to put my finger on why there have been more people in the park as it's not a science," said Alborn. "I don't know how, but about 40 years it got on the bucket list for a lot of Europeans." Ad Feedback 
There had been more people doing shorter, one way trips from Marahau and an increase in the number of Chinese visitors, said Alborn. 
Nelson Tasman Tourism chief executive Lynda Keene said it was encouraging to see more New Zealanders and international visitors enjoying the national parks. 
"There is no doubt that the Abel Tasman National Park is the iconic visitor experience in the region," she said. 
The work that DOC had been doing with Nelson Tasman Tourism and Air New Zealand to promote the Great Walks had been critical in raising the profile of the Abel Tasman Coast Track which had benefits for the supporting communities and businesses. 
One of those enjoying the park yesterday was Alison Maccoll of Christchurch, who had driven up to do a day walk on the coastal track. 
"I've done a little bit of walking from the other end but never from the Marahau end so it was just to come and have a day out," said Maccoll. - Stuff
